text: The righteous shall see it, and rejoice: and all iniquity shall stop her mouth.
text_kjv: The righteous shall see it, and rejoice: and all iniquity shall stop her mouth.
text_niv: The upright see and rejoice,but all the wicked shut their mouths.
text_esv: The upright see it and are glad, and all wickedness shuts its mouth.
text_nlt: The godly will see these things and be glad,while the wicked are struck silent.
text_msg: Good people see this and are glad;bad people are speechless, stopped in their tracks.
text_nasb: The upright see it and are glad; But all unrighteousness shuts its mouth.
context: Psalm 107 is a psalm of thanksgiving, celebrating God's deliverance of his people from various trials. It likely originated after a period of national hardship, possibly the Babylonian exile, when the Israelites experienced significant suffering and were subsequently restored to their land. The psalm follows a recurring pattern: a description of distress, a cry for help, God's deliverance, and a call to thanksgiving. This repetitive structure emphasizes the consistent faithfulness of God in the face of diverse adversities. Verse 42 stands as a culmination of the testimonies within the psalm. The concept of 'righteous' in the Old Testament often referred to those who were in covenant with God and lived according to His laws. 'Iniquity' embodies moral wrong doing and wickedness. The stopping of the mouth suggests being silenced by overwhelming evidence or divine judgment. In ancient Near Eastern cultures, public pronouncements and speeches held significant weight, so the inability to speak signified powerlessness and defeat. The psalm's language reflects the historical experiences of Israel and the poetic conventions of Hebrew literature, employing vivid imagery to portray both suffering and salvation. The joy of the righteous and the silencing of iniquity highlight the ultimate triumph of God's justice and the vindication of His people.
meaning: Theologically, Psalm 107:42 encapsulates the core tenets of divine justice and the ultimate vindication of the righteous. 'The righteous shall see it, and rejoice' speaks to the assurance that God is not indifferent to suffering or injustice. They witness God's intervention and their joy stems from knowing that His promises are true and His character is just. The rejoicing isn't just personal; it is a confirmation of God's covenant faithfulness and the ultimate triumph of good over evil. 'All iniquity shall stop her mouth' signifies the ultimate defeat of wickedness. It portrays a scenario where evil is rendered powerless, unable to speak, defend itself, or continue its destructive course. This silencing is not merely a cessation of activity but a recognition of the truth: that God is sovereign and His justice will ultimately prevail. This verse underscores the concept of divine judgment, where wrongdoers will be held accountable for their actions. The theological significance lies in the verse affirming that God's kingdom will ultimately be established, where righteousness reigns and injustice is vanquished. It offers hope and encouragement to those who suffer for righteousness' sake, reminding them that their faithfulness is not in vain. The psalm's overall message, culminating in this verse, points to the redemptive power of God and the eventual establishment of His just and righteous rule.
application: In modern life, Psalm 107:42 provides profound encouragement and a call to action. 'The righteous shall see it, and rejoice' invites us to actively seek and recognize God's hand in our lives and the world around us. This means cultivating a perspective that looks beyond immediate circumstances to see the underlying truth of God's sovereignty and goodness. We should seek out and celebrate instances where justice prevails, where truth triumphs over falsehood, and where God's love is manifested. This active recognition fuels our joy and strengthens our faith, even amidst ongoing challenges. Furthermore, the verse compels us to stand firm in our commitment to righteousness, even when it is unpopular or difficult. This includes speaking truth to power, advocating for the marginalized, and living lives that reflect God's values. We need to be sources of justice and truth in our communities, even if it means facing opposition. When 'all iniquity shall stop her mouth,' it reminds us that evil will not have the last word. This encourages perseverance, hope, and steadfast faith even when darkness seems to surround us. Practically, this means trusting God's promises, even when we don't see immediate results. It encourages us to work towards justice, knowing that our efforts, however small, contribute to God's ultimate plan of redemption. It calls us to silence the voices of doubt and fear, and to instead speak words of hope and encouragement to ourselves and others. It also cautions against becoming complacent or apathetic in the face of injustice, urging us to actively participate in bringing about a more just and equitable world.
prayer: Heavenly Father, thank you for the promise of justice and the assurance that You see and value the righteous. Help us to cultivate eyes that recognize Your hand at work in the world, celebrating the victories of truth and the triumphs of good over evil. Grant us the strength to stand firm in our commitment to righteousness, even when it is difficult. Empower us to speak truth to power and to advocate for those who are marginalized. When we face doubt and fear, remind us that You are sovereign and that evil will not have the last word. Fill our hearts with hope and perseverance, enabling us to trust in Your promises, even when we cannot see the way forward. Help us to be instruments of Your justice and love in the world. In Jesus' name, Amen.

faqs.answer: To 'see it' implies more than mere observation. It signifies understanding and recognizing God's hand at work, perceiving His justice, and acknowledging His faithfulness. It's seeing with spiritual discernment.
faqs.question: Q1: What does it mean for the 'righteous' to 'see it'?

faqs.answer: Rejoicing strengthens our faith, renews our hope, and motivates us to continue pursuing righteousness. It affirms our belief in a just God and empowers us to persevere through trials.
faqs.question: Q2: How does rejoicing in God's justice benefit us?

faqs.answer: It signifies the silencing and defeat of wickedness. It suggests that falsehood and injustice are rendered powerless and unable to continue their destructive course, by God's power.
faqs.question: Q3: What does it mean for 'iniquity' to 'stop her mouth'?

faqs.answer: While it anticipates ultimate justice, its principles apply now. We can see glimpses of God's justice in our lives and communities, encouraging us to live righteously today.
faqs.question: Q4: Is this verse only applicable at the end of time?

faqs.answer: Pray for discernment, study scripture, reflect on your experiences, and actively look for examples of God's justice and goodness. Seek to understand and learn from these things.
faqs.question: Q5: How can I actively seek to 'see it' in my daily life?
